ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to conduct human robotics interaction research
I learned how to design a robotics experiment from start to finish. I also got to learn about and discuss many different fields in robotics.
Research methodology, evaluating research papers and experiment design, understanding the different aspects of robotic design, general knowledge about robotics.

I learned how to develop a research project idea. I learned how to work with the Universal Robots arm and some about using ROS to interface hardware. I learned SolidWorks and more about CADing parts. I learned about current research in robotics, including about topics like agricultural robots, surgical robots, space robotics, robot abuse, and delivery robots. I learned how to put together a 15-20 minute lecture about a research topic and how to effectively read research papers. I learned how to use pre-trained neural networks and RealSense cameras.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is really hands-on and the paper discussions are really interesting

The topics discussed in the class were always fascinating. For the project itself, the timing of spring break breaking into the project was tough. It was also hard to find workarounds for hardware/software that we may have needed but didn't realize we needed until it was too late in the semester.
I really enjoyed the fact that the class is a seminar course in addition to the project, and the materials and topics we covered were very important

I like the format of the course a lot. Each lecture consists of a 15-20 minute student presentation on a current robotics research topic, followed by a relevant class discussion. You do one hands-on lab project (in a group) over the course of the whole semester, which means you have lots of room to be creative and build or study something that's interesting to you. Advising by Scaz and Debasmita is superb (and also rigorous).
Feedback could be improved; you don't get any feedback about your presentation which I think would have been nice. The only real feedback you get is after each check-in presentation, which is not often. But that feedback is good feedback.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this course provides a hands on experience on how to conduct research from start to finish
Would recommend this course if you want to get really hands on and have a project to really call your own from start to finish. It's a lot more work than it seems
Yes, it's a challenging course but you can learn a great deal

Yes, I'd definitely recommend it, especially if you love project-based courses or have an idea for a robotics project with useful applications that you want to realize. There are no exams and you won't receive any grades throughout the course, so keep that in mind. But this class lets you be creative. It'll also teach you a lot about how the Internal Review Board approval process works. That process can be a pain. This course also gives you the opportunity to do a real human subjects study and write a real conference-level research paper! And there's a big budget for ordering hardware.
